In addition, the Chief Electoral Officer will not produce for the purpose of communicating with citizens any new lists of electors while a health emergency is in effect.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning the municipalities during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will regional elected representatives be able to use the money paid to them from the Fonds reÃÅgions et ruraliteÃÅ (FRR) to provide direct support to businesses affected by measures to combat COVID-19?
reference.section_content: The government is currently developing assistance measures specifically for Quebec businesses affected by COVID-19 control measures. These assistance measures will be funded with amounts separate from those in the FRR. It is therefore recommended that regional elected officials wait until they are informed of the new government support measures for businesses before determining how they will be able to intervene in a complementary manner, using the amounts made available to them through the FRR.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning the municipalities during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How should the RCM use the funds from part 2 of the FRR (which has replaced the Fonds de deÃÅveloppement des territoires) if it decides to implement assistance specifically for businesses affected by the fight against COVID-19?
reference.section_content: An RCM must comply with the conditions for using the fund set out in the Agreement respecting the Fonds reÃÅgions et ruraliteÃÅ, part2 - support for the local and regional development jurisdiction of RCMs (hereinafter referred to as "the Agreement").An RCM that does not comply with the conditions set out in the Agreement is in default.In the event of default, the Minister may take various measures listed in clause71 of the Agreement.As an example, here are the main conditions that the RCM has committed to respecting: The RCM may not award a grant to a private firm exceeding50% of the total eligible expenses of the supported project (clause30). The RCM may not use RRF funds to make loans. Expenses incurred to support a project in the retail or restaurant sector are not eligible, except for local services (clause29 and AppendixA). The notion of proximity service must be consistent with the rules that the RCM has established on this subject (clause20.3). No expenses related to projects already carried out are eligible. A plan or support measures must be integrated into the RCM's intervention priorities for the current year. If necessary, the RCM may update its priorities by resolution, publish them on its website, and forward them to the Minister (clauses13.1 and 18 of the Agreement). The plan or measures must be integrated into the RCM's business support policy and its support policy for structuring projects to improve its communities. If necessary, the RCM may update its policies, publish them on its website, and forward them to the Minister (clauses13.2 and 20 to 23 of the Agreement). The ministeÃÄre des Affaires municipales et de l‚ÄôHabitation's regional branches are available to assist the municipal community with any questions on this subject.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a person choose which residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD) they want to go to?
reference.section_content: A person can always say where they would like to go. However, during the pandemic, the facility will prioritize access based on the person‚Äôs needs and the availability of places. If the CHSLD recommended is not the one the person wants to go to, a transfer to the facility they want to go to will be arranged once the pandemic is over.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can essential items be delivered to people in residential and long-term care centres (CHSLDs)?
reference.section_content: Some essential items that are not available in the CHSLD can be delivered to residents. Precautions must be taken when delivering items to prevent contact with anyone in the CHSLD. You must leave immediately after giving the items to a staff member at reception. Always keep your distance from other people, avoid direct contact and practice cough and sneeze etiquette as usual. All laundry will be done by the CHSLD for residents. This temporary measure will limit interaction with the outside world and help prevent the spread of the virus.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can people who live in residential and long-term care centres (CHSLDs) leave the centre to go to their medical appointments?
reference.section_content: Residents are being asked to stay in the CHSLD. They are allowed to go out when necessary or in exceptional circumstances, such as to go to an essential medical appointment. When they return to the CHSLD, the required infection prevention and control measures will be taken.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I move my loved one out of their residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD) and care for them in my own home?
reference.section_content: You can move someone who is living in a CHSLD out and care for them in your own home. However, certain rules apply: Your loved one must be made aware of the implications of the decision. For example:They will not be able to receive home care services of the same standard as the care and services provided in the CHSLD.When they return to the CHSLD, before or after the pandemic is over, they will have to go through the access mechanism to obtain a place in a CHSLD. This means that their room may have been given to another resident.You must consider your loved one‚Äôs medication needs if they leave the CHSLD. You must make sure they will continue to take their medication.Your loved one will have to go to or be brought to the entrance of the CHSLD so that you do not have to go inside. You will be responsible for arranging transportation.If the person has significant home care needs, the facility may refuse to allow them to leave in the interest of their safety, given the limited capacity of home care teams at the moment due to the pandemic.If a resident is incompetent, the facility must make sure they obtain consent from the legal representative before authorizing the resident to leave.You may have to go to a region that is in lockdown to move your loved one out of their CHSLD. This will be considered interregional travel for humanitarian reasons. Written confirmation from the CHSLD may make it easier to get through road checkpoints.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I move my loved one out of a residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD) where there are COVID-19 cases and care for them in my own home?
reference.section_content: You can move a loved one out of a CHSLD where cases of COVID‚Äê19 have been reported out and care for them in your own home. However, it is recommended that infection prevention and control measures be put in place to minimize the risk of contamination in your home. You should follow these instructions: All members of the household must wash their hands frequently.As much as possible, a distance of 2 meters must be maintained between people in the home.Do not have visitors to the home.The person you are caring for must not go out to visit other family members or to go to a public place (for example, grocery store, pharmacy, bank, etc.);If the person you are caring for has to go out for health care, they must have an appointment. They should avoid using public transit and should maintain a distance of 2 meters from other people, as much as possible;Other members of the household must only go out when necessary and must follow strict hand hygiene measures before, during and after doing so;High-touch items and surfaces, such as door handles, faucets, switches and stair rails should be cleaned and disinfected often. If any of the following situations apply to your loved one who lives in a CHSLD or to a member of your household, you will not, temporarily, be able to have your loved one stay with you: The person who wishes to leave a facility or one of the people in the household where they would be staying has one or more symptoms of COVID‚Äê19 (unusual cough, fever, difficulty breathing, sudden loss of sense of smell without a stuffy nose, with or without loss of sense of taste);The person who wishes to leave a facility or one of the people in the household where they would be staying has specifically been told to self-isolate by public health because they:have had close contact (high or moderate risk exposure) with a confirmed case of COVID-19;are waiting for a COVID‚Äê19 test result. In these situations, you will have to wait until the person is allowed to end their self-isolation before making arrangements to move your loved one out of the CHSLD.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How can I stay in touch with a loved one who lives in a residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD)?
reference.section_content: Staff in CHSLDs understand that it is important for residents to stay connected with family and friends. If necessary, CHSLD staff can help the resident use the telephone or an alternative method of communication so that they can stay in touch with family and friends. In addition, people designated by the CHSLD will be responsible for contacting families or friends regularly to keep them informed of the resident‚Äôs health and well-being.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can residents continue to have their meals in the residential and long-term care centre‚Äôs (CHSLD) dining room and take part in leisure activities?
reference.section_content: It depends on whether or not the resident is able to eat on their own. During the pandemic, CHSLDs have to reduce the number of people in the dining room by 50% in order to keep a distance of 2 metres between people. Consequently, only residents who need help or close supervision during meals are allowed to go to the dining room. Residents who are able to eat on their own must have their meals in their room. However, staff will offer to prepare the tray completely for them when it is delivered (open containers, cut up food, etc.) In addition, a person will be designated to supervise and attend to the needs of residents who have their meals in their room, for example, if a resident drops a utensil.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are people who live in residential and long-term care centres (CHSLDs) allowed to go out?
reference.section_content: Residents are not allowed to go out, since they might bring the virus into the CHSLD when they return. This includes visits to their families.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I visit someone who lives in a residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD) in an end-of-life situation?
reference.section_content: CHSLDs allow visits for humanitarian reasons, such as when death is imminent (24-48 hours). A maximum of two visitors are allowed at a time. CHSLD staff will screen visitors for symptoms of COVID-19. If they have symptoms, special measures will be taken to keep residents and staff safe. Then, visitors will be escorted to make sure they comply with infection prevention and control measures. Their visit will be restricted to the location where their dying loved one is. If a resident is in isolation because of COVID-19, staff will have to help visitors put on and take off the necessary personal protective equipment.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What rules have been put in place to prevent staff from spreading the virus in the residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD)?
reference.section_content: Everyone who works in the CHSLD must comply with basic infection prevention and control practices: wash their hands often with soap under warm running water for at least 20 seconds or use an alcohol-based hand rub;cover their mouth and nose with their arm to reduce the spread of germs if they cough or sneeze;use a tissue to blow their nose, dispose of it as soon as possible and wash their hands afterwards;avoid direct contact when they greet someone, such as shaking hands. In addition, staff use personal protective equipment as recommended by the facility‚Äôs infection prevention and control teams and by the Institut national de santeÃÅ publique du QueÃÅbec.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What happens if one of the residents in the residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD) has symptoms of COVID-19?
reference.section_content: If a resident has symptoms of COVID-19, they must be separated from other residents immediately. Infection prevention and control measures are increased. The resident‚Äôs health is monitored constantly.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a hairdresser still provide their services in the residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD)?
reference.section_content: Since it is impossible for a hairdresser to keep a distance of 2 metres from their client and since a no-visitor policy has been implemented in CHSLDs, hairdressing services cannot be maintained.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can an informal or family caregiver provide support to someone who lives in a residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD)?
reference.section_content: Although visits have been suspended, a significant caregiver can provide support to someone who lives in a CHSLD provided they comply with certain conditions. To be provided with support by a significant caregiver, CHSLD residents must have received support from the person before visiting restrictions were put in place due to COVID‚Äê19. As of May 11, 2020, caregivers will have to comply with certain measures. In particular, they will have to: Wear a procedure mask at all times;Practice strict hand hygiene;Monitor themselves closely forsymptoms;The caregiver may be asked to use additional personal protective equipment depending on the resident‚Äôs condition.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a gift be delivered to someone in residential and long-term care centre (CHSLD) for Mother's Day, Father's Day or on some other occasion?
reference.section_content: A gift can be delivered to a resident in a CHSLD. However, there may be some exceptions, depending on the CHSLD, check with it before having a gift delivered. Home-cooked meals can be accepted. However, the container must be able to be disinfected before being transmitted to the resident. Flower delivery can be accepted. Flowers, like all other gifts, must be placed at the entrance, wrapped.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can pregnant women who are giving birth be accompanied by a loved one?
reference.section_content: At present, pregnant women can be accompanied by a loved one when giving birth in QueÃÅbec hospitals. However, hospitals may adopt certain specific measures, as is the case at the Montreal Jewish General Hospital. To obtain additional information in this regard, pregnant women can contact their hospital.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should I do if I need a medical consultation during the pandemic?
reference.section_content: Regardless of why you need a medical consultation, if you have flu-like symptoms, gastroenteritis or symptoms of COVID‚Äê19, call418‚Äê644‚Äê4545,450‚Äê644‚Äê4545,514‚Äê644‚Äê4545,819‚Äê644‚Äê4545or1‚Äê877‚Äê644‚Äê4545(toll free) and you will be referred to the appropriate resource. If you do not haveflu-like symptoms,gastroenteritisor symptoms ofCOVID‚Äê19, you can always consult if you need to by, contacting your family doctor, medical clinic or family medicine group (FMG) to make an appointment for a consultation over the telephone or in person. If you are unable to reach your medical clinic or are not registered with a family doctor, you can call Info‚ÄêSanteÃÅ 811 to speak to a nurse, get advice about what to do and be referred, if necessary, to the appropriate resource. People who have a chronic disease (e.g., diabetes, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, degenerative disease, etc.), cancer or any other disease or condition that requires regular health follow-up are, in particular, encouraged to have these follow-ups and go to their medical appointments.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Does the RAMQ cover health services provided by means of telecommunications?
reference.section_content: Yes, the RAMQ will from now on cover health services provided by correspondence or by means of telecommunications. This coverage includes, for example, a telephone consultation with a physician.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What can I do if I am an informal caregiver and feel that my everyday life has been disrupted?
reference.section_content: Due to the pandemic, many informal caregivers find that their everyday life has been disrupted. You may be wondering what the best way to support your loved one is. You have to solve practical problems, provide moral support, perhaps help them out financially too. Caregiver Support Helplinecounsellors are there to listen to you, answer your questions and, if necessary, refer you to programs and resources that can help you in your everyday life. Do not hesitate to call them at1 855 852‚Äê7784or to visit theCaregiver Supportwebsite.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are visits to private seniors‚Äô residences (RPA) allowed?
reference.section_content: Since March 13, 2020, non-essential visits to RPA have been prohibited in order to protect the most vulnerable and workers in the health and social services network.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can food be delivered to people in private seniors‚Äô residences (RPA)?
reference.section_content: Food can be delivered to RPA. Precautions must be taken when delivering food to prevent contact with anyone in the residence. You must leave immediately after giving the food to a staff member at reception. Always keep your distance from other people, avoid direct contact and practice cough and sneeze etiquette as usual.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can essential items be delivered to people in private seniors‚Äô residences (RPA)?
reference.section_content: Some essential items that are not available in the residence can be delivered to residents. Precautions must be taken when delivering items to prevent contact with anyone in the residence. You must leave immediately after giving the items to a staff member at reception. Always keep your distance from other people, avoid direct contact and practice cough and sneeze etiquette as usual.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can people who live in private seniors‚Äô residences (RPA) leave the residence to go to their medical appointments?
reference.section_content: They are allowed to go out, such as to go to a medical appointment. Before you go to your appointment, make sure it has not been cancelled due to the pandemic. If it has not been cancelled and you are unable to go on your own, another person can accompany you provided they: do not havesymptoms of COVID-19;have not been travelling in the last 14 days;have not had contact with a person who has COVID-19 or thinks they have it. The person must keep at least 2 meters away from you the entire time and follow all recommendations for preventing the spread of the virus. When you return to the residence, all infection prevention and control measures must be rigorously applied. For example, you must: wash your hands often with soap under warm running water for at least 20 seconds or use an alcohol-based hand rub;cover your mouth and nose with your arm to reduce the spread of germs if you cough or sneeze. If you use a tissue, dispose of it as soon as possible and wash your hands afterwards;avoid direct contact when you greet someone, such as shaking hands.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are residents still allowed to leave the private seniors‚Äô residence (RPA) to visit family, run errands or take a walk?
reference.section_content: It is recommended that visits be limited to close family. However, all residents of private seniors‚Äô homes, including those age 70 or older, are now allowed to go out for a walk and to run essential errands (grocery store, pharmacy, etc.) provided they comply with all of the following conditions: keep 2 metres away from other people at all times;avoid gatherings;follow all the infection prevention and control measures recommended by public health when they return.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I move my loved one out of their private seniors‚Äô residence (RPA) and care for them in my own home?
reference.section_content: You can move a loved one out of their RPA out and care for them in your own home. However, certain rules apply: Your loved one must be made aware of the implications of the decision. For example:They will not be able to receive home care services of the same standard as the care and services they may be receiving in the RPA.They will remain subject to the regulations in effect regarding their lease.You must consider your loved one‚Äôs medication needs if they leave the residence. To ensure they continue to take their medication, you will have make sure they have an adequate supply.Your loved one will have to go to or be brought to the entrance so that you do not have to go inside. You will be responsible for arranging transportation.If the person has significant home care needs, the facility may refuse to allow them to leave in the interest of their safety, given the limited capacity of home care teams at the moment due to the pandemic. You may have to go to a region that is in lockdown to move your loved one out of a RPA. This will be considered interregional travel for humanitarian reasons. Written confirmation from the residence may make it easier to get through road checkpoints.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I move my loved one out of a private seniors‚Äô residence (RPA) where there are COVID-19 cases and care for them in my own home?
reference.section_content: You can move a loved one out of a RPA where cases of COVID‚Äê19 have been reported out and care for them in your own home. However, it is recommended that infection prevention and control measures be put in place to minimize the risk of contamination in your home. You should follow these instructions: All members of the household must wash their hands frequently.As much as possible, a distance of 2 meters must be maintained between people in the home.Do not have visitors to the home.The person you are caring for must not go out to visit other family members or to go to a public place (for example, grocery store, pharmacy, bank, etc.);If the person you are caring for has to go out for health care, they must have an appointment. They should avoid using public transit and should maintain a distance of 2 meters from other people, as much as possible;Other members of the household must only go out when necessary and must follow strict hand hygiene measures before, during and after doing so;High-touch items and surfaces, such as door handles, faucets, switches and stair rails should be cleaned and disinfected often. If any of the following situations apply to your loved one who lives in a RPA or to a member of your household, you will not, temporarily, be able to have your loved one stay with you: The person who wishes to leave a facility or one of the people in the household where they would be staying has one or more symptoms of COVID‚Äê19 (unusual cough, fever, difficulty breathing, sudden loss of sense of smell without a stuffy nose, with or without loss of sense of taste);The person who wishes to leave a facility or one of the people in the household where they would be staying has specifically been told to self-isolate by public health because they:have had close contact (high or moderate risk exposure) with a confirmed case of COVID‚Äê19;are waiting for a COVID‚Äê19 test result. In these situations, you will have to wait until the person is allowed to end their self-isolation before making arrangements to move your loved one out of the RPA.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it still possible to visit a private seniors‚Äô residence (RPA) before I decide whether or not to move in and sign a lease?
reference.section_content: At this time, all visits to RPA are prohibited. Virtual visits are recommended if a new resident would like to see their future home before they sign a lease.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a private seniors‚Äô residence (RPA) charge for bringing meals to a resident's room or apartment because of COVID-19?
reference.section_content: Residences are not allowed to charge for meal delivery during the pandemic.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a gift be delivered to people in private seniors' residence (RPA) for Mother's Day, Father's Day or some other occasion?
reference.section_content: A gift can be delivered to a resident in a RPA. However, there may be some exceptions depending on the RPA, check with it before having a gift delivered. Home-cooked meals can be accepted. However, the container must be able to be disinfected before being transmitted to the resident. Flower delivery can be accepted. Flowers, like all other gifts, must be placed at the entrance, wrapped.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on health services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can an informal or family caregiver provide support to someone who lives in private seniors‚Äô residences (RPA)?
reference.section_content: Although visits have been suspended, a significant caregiver can provide support to someone who lives in RPA provided they comply with certain conditions. To be provided with support by a significant caregiver, RPA residents must have received support from the person before visiting restrictions were put in place due to COVID‚Äê19. As of May 11, 2020, caregivers will have to comply with certain measures. In particular, they will have to: Wear a procedure mask at all times;Practice strict hand hygiene;Monitor themselves closely forsymptoms;The caregiver may be asked to use additional personal protective equipment depending on the resident‚Äôs condition.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should I do if my child or I experience skin irritation or allergic or inflammatory reactions when we wash our hands with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer, such as Purell¬Æ or Bacti Control¬Æ?
reference.section_content: If you or your child experience skin irritation or an allergic or inflammatory reaction when you wash your hands with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer, please stop using the product. Use soap and water to wash your hands instead. Frequent handwashing and washing your hands with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer can dry out the skin. To prevent dry skin, it is recommended that you use moisturizer on your hands every day. If the skin irritation or reactions persist, you should see a doctor.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What is the plan for the progressive return to classes?
reference.section_content: Public and private schools Preschools and elementary schools are gradually resuming their activities in all regions of QueÃÅbec, with the exception of schools located in theCommunauteÃÅ meÃÅtropolitaine de MontreÃÅal(In French only) (MontreÃÅal metropolitan community, CMM), which will remain closed to students until the end of August. The exceptions made for the territory of the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community also apply for the territory of the regional county municipality of Joliette. Secondary schools will remain closed until the end of August, following recommendations by public health authorities. Students will consolidate their distance learning through increased pedagogical support. Administrative centres will continue to carry out essential activities; they therefore remain open. However, until schools reopen in their regions, administrative staff members are asked to work remotely whenever possible.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which schools will reopen on May 11?
reference.section_content: Preschools and elementary schools are gradually resuming their activities in all regions of QueÃÅbec, with the exception of schools located in theCommunauteÃÅ meÃÅtropolitaine de MontreÃÅal(In French only) (MontreÃÅal metropolitan community, CMM), which will remain closed to students until the end of August. The exceptions made for the territory of the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community also apply for the territory of the regional county municipality of Joliette. Some secondary schools will also reopen, specifically public schools that offer regional or supraregional schooling services as well as private schools specialized in special education for students with disabilities or severe behavioral issues. Schools in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community will reopen on May 25, health conditions permitting. Secondary schools will remain closed until the end of August, following recommendations by public health authorities.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What about vocational training?
reference.section_content: As of May 11, vocational training students may continue their learning activities, but they will use a variety of methods (online, distance learning, etc.). Vocational training centres located in the Montreal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette will remain closed to students until the end of August. Vocational training staff will also resume their duties, either at a distance or in person, depending on the different programs and according to physical distancing rules. Where possible, distance learning and teleworking should be favoured in this context. However, should the students‚Äô presence be required on site for practical learning or for certain evaluations, it is prohibited for more than 50% of students to be present at a time. Students will be accommodated according to physical distancing rules.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will adult learners be allowed to write exams in adult education centres?
reference.section_content: As of May 11, adult learners may continue their learning activities, but they will use a variety of methods (online, distance learning, etc.). Adult education centres located in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette will remain closed to students until the end of August. Adult learners may access adult education centres to write exams as of May 11, with the exception of those located in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette (May 25 in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette). However, classrooms must not exceed an adult learner capacity of 50% at all times during evaluation situations, in accordance with physical distancing rules.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will these measures be put in place in the English sector?
reference.section_content: The measures put in place in the French sector will also apply in the English sector.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Why open the elementary schools and not the secondary schools?
reference.section_content: In general, elementary schools tend to be smaller than secondary schools. Secondary school students are more independent and are in a better position to finish their school year through distance learning. Teachers will provide pedagogical support, and sites such asecoleouverte.ca, and educational activities kits will continue to be made available to elementary students, particularly those whose parents choose not to send them back to school.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a parent decide to send their child to school at any time?
reference.section_content: Parents are not obliged to send their children back to school. Parents may decide to send them back to school after May 11, but they must give the school administration one week‚Äôs notice to allow for the organization of school transportation and pedagogical supervision in the classrooms.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What measures will be put in place to ensure the health and safety of children and staff?
reference.section_content: School organization will be based on public health recommendations, which are constantly evolving and can vary from region to region. Each school will take measures to respect the physical distancing recommendation of maintaining at least 2 metres between students. Where possible while following this recommendation, each group can have a maximum of 15 students. A variety of means can be used for groups where more than 15 students wish to return to school, such as reforming different groups of students at the same grade level, with each group staying in the same classroom until the end of the school year while respecting the 2-metre rule between individuals, for example. Visitors will not be allowed to enter the school.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will specific measures be taken when students and personnel return to educational institutions?
reference.section_content: The premises will be subject to regular, appropriate maintenance to ensure their cleanliness. Efforts will be made to raise awareness about proper handwashing and respiratory hygiene. Hygiene and sanitation measures are being implemented in schools, as per public health recommendations.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What if classroom configuration doesn‚Äôt respect the 2 metre distancing rule?
reference.section_content: Each school will take measures to ensure that students stay the recommended 2 metres apart. School teams must carefully plan student groups according to the space they have available. It is possible that a child might not return to their usual classroom, as the groups will have to be smaller than usual. School teams must be particularly careful to set up the necessary supervision so that students remain at least 2 metres apart and wash their hands regularly. It is essential that teachers and parents collaborate in explaining these rules to the children.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Isn‚Äôt it risky to put 15 children together in the same group all day?
reference.section_content: The application of public health rules is at the heart of this return to normal life. Incidentally, 15 is the maximum number of children allowed per group, but fewer than 15 will be accepted into a group if a classroom is too small for it to respect the 2-metre physical distancing rule. Children will be assigned to a group and to a teacher, and measures will be taken to ensure that large groups of children are never in contact or together at the same time, such as having staggered recess times, with small groups of children. School organization will certainly look different. However, since the beginning of the pandemic, emergency daycare services have been set up in more than 350 elementary schools all across QueÃÅbec and have managed to adapt to the new measures. On the strength of the experience acquired in this context, and in collaboration with the public health authorities in each region, the school teams will ensure the safety of children and staff with care and vigilance.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What if there are more than 15 students in a class?
reference.section_content: Each school will take steps to enforce physical distancing rules, thereby making sure to reduce the risk level. Different methods can be used if a group of more than 15 students wishes to return to school, such as reforming different groups of students at the same grade level, with each group staying in the same classroom until the end of the school year while respecting the 2-metre rule, for example.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How will travel in the hallways, at recess and during lunch hour be managed to ensure everyone‚Äôs safety?
reference.section_content: Schools will have to limit travel within the school, minimize times when groups travel at the same time and use staggered schedules. They will use one room for classes, lunch and daycare. They will take turns using the schoolyard. Students must wash their hands regularly and avoid physical contact with each other.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will regular schedules be adjusted in elementary schools?
reference.section_content: Elementary schools are given the flexibility to adjust their schedules. For example, students could arrive and leave at different times to avoid gatherings.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will the students and teachers be required to wear a mask?
reference.section_content: No, wearing a mask is not compulsory. However, the government has confirmed that face coverings may be provided to teachers who request them. Measures will also be taken by each educational institution to comply with the physical distancing rule of maintaining 2 metres between students. Students or staff members with symptoms of COVID-19 must not enter the school. Any person who receives a diagnosis of COVID-19 must comply with a 14-day isolation period.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will there be COVID-19 screening tests in schools?
reference.section_content: No. Like the rest of the population, students who are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms must stay at home and contact a health care professional. ASelf-Care Guidewith information on the necessary steps to take has been made available to Quebecers. More information on the health guidelines to follow, especially who to contact in order to get tested, is available onQueÃÅbec.ca.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should I do if my child has a pre-existing health condition?
reference.section_content: Parents are not obliged to send their children back to school. However, returning to school is not recommended before September 2020 for children who are vulnerable for health reasons (chronic disease, severe immunodeficiency, etc.). Pedagogical support will be provided to these students.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should I do if I am a parent with a pre-existing health condition?
reference.section_content: Parents do not have the obligation to send their children back to school. However, as a precautionary measure, the presence at school of a child whose parents have a health vulnerability (chronic disease, severe immunodeficiency, pregnancy or person aged 70 or over) should rather be privileged from September 2020. By then, parents could opt for distance learning, with the support of members of the school staff.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: If I decide to keep my child at home, will they have access to pedagogical services?
reference.section_content: School attendance will remain non-compulsory until the end of the school year. Pedagogical support will be provided by teachers to all of their students, including those who do not return to the classroom. Those students will be provided with schoolwork by their teachers, who will also carry out a weekly follow-up with them. Since student advancement to the next grade level is determined by teachers‚Äô professional judgment, teachers will be able to use online schoolwork or evaluations to validate their judgments of certain learning content. In addition, in order to continue fostering learning by preschool, elementary and secondary students, the MinisteÃÄre will continue to offer educational activities on theOpen Schooland on TeÃÅleÃÅ-QueÃÅbec. website and on TeÃÅleÃÅ-QueÃÅbec.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: My child has learning difficulties. What measures will be put in place?
reference.section_content: Vulnerable students are strongly encouraged to return to the classroom as soon as possible to be able to benefit from optimal pedagogical support. School staff will contact the parents to reassure them and provide appropriate support during the return to the classroom. The members of the school teams will increase the weekly personalized follow-up with their students, giving priority to the most vulnerable students and using‚Äîfor students who are not in the classroom‚Äîa technological tool allowing direct contact (e.g. telephone, video call).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are vulnerable employees required to remain confined and not return to school?
reference.section_content: Being present on the school premises is not recommended for staff members who are vulnerable for health reasons (chronic disease, severe immunodeficiency, pregnancy or aged 70 or older). For health and safety reasons, these staff members are encouraged to delay their return to school until September 2020.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What measures will be put in place if a case is declared in a school?
reference.section_content: As soon as a case is confirmed, the child is isolated in a room and cannot return to school for a period of 14 days. Schools have received an emergency kit to be used when a case of COVID-19 is confirmed. The public health authority in the region concerned will assess the situation and issue appropriate instructions.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What measures are planned if a student or a staff member has symptoms of COVID-19?
reference.section_content: The student or staff member will be prohibited from being on the school premises until they have been symptom-free for 24 to 48 hours. Pedagogical support will be provided to the student during this period.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will school transportation be provided?
reference.section_content: Yes, school transportation will resume as soon as schools reopen, and the routes will be established based on the needs. Strict measures determined by the public health authority must be respected, including a limit of one child per bench. Every second bench must remain empty. The driver must be provided with a protective zone. In the event it is not possible to create a protective zone, drivers may wear the protective equipment provided. It is recommended that parents transport their child to school until the end of the school year if they are able to do so.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will additional school transportation be provided to respect the guideline of one child per bench?
reference.section_content: Parents must inform the school as to whether they want their child to use school transportation, and the school will organize transportation based on the needs. It is recommended that parents transport their child to school until the end of the school year if they are able to do so.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will the regular daycare services be provided in the schools?
reference.section_content: Starting on May 11, as preschools and elementary schools in some regions reopen, school daycare services will resume regular operations in every school. Any family with children enrolled at a school can register for that school‚Äôs daycare services, if needed, by following the standard local procedures. In the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community, emergency daycare services will remain open until June 30, inclusive. The exceptions made for the territory of the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community also apply for the territory of the regional county municipality of Joliette. As this is a return to normal activities, students must register directly at the school where they are enrolled.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will new content be taught between now and the end of the school year?
reference.section_content: The main objective of the return to the classroom and of the support for students remaining at home will be to reinforce the essential learning required to move up to the next grade level.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will students have to make up this lost school time this summer?
reference.section_content: No, the school year will not be extended into summer.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will there be an impact on the transition from elementary to secondary school and secondary school to CEGEP for graduating students?
reference.section_content: Student advancement to the next grade level will be determined by the students‚Äô evaluations carried out before schools closed on March 13. In addition, teachers are asked to determine the students‚Äô results for the last report card based on their knowledge of the students‚Äô acquired learning. No matter the level, schools must plan for a review period at the beginning of the 2020-2021 school year.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Considering the severe shortage of substitute teachers that existed before the pandemic, will there be enough teachers to act as replacements if necessary?
reference.section_content: At the moment, it is difficult to predict the needs for educational staff as the number of students that will be present in schools is not yet known. However, the limitations imposed by physical distancing, that is, maintaining 2 metres between individuals, and the exclusion of employees who are vulnerable for health reasons will create added pressure on the availability of elementary school teachers. If necessary, secondary school teachers on permanent contracts will be asked to step in, with the support of professionals and support staff in elementary schools. The order allowing for this redeployment of resources must come from a reassignment measure from the local union, if necessary.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do students have to write the ministerial examinations?
reference.section_content: No. The ministerial examinations will not be administered. Students were unable to acquire all the learning targeted by the programs of study because of the health crisis that caused educational services to be suspended for a considerable amount of time.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can the government grant diplomas to students who have not written their final or ministerial exams?
reference.section_content: The government can, if the circumstances warrant it, cancel an examination and use the marks awarded by the school as a final grade. Due to the current exceptional circumstances, the ministerial examinations will be cancelled, and the school results will be taken into account in the awarding of diplomas. Students will move up to the next grade level based on the teachers‚Äô professional judgment and the students‚Äô previous results on the first two report cards.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are room rental and infrastructure sharing agreements maintained?
reference.section_content: Non-essential activities like infrastructure sharing are temporarily interrupted in order to slow the spread of the virus, as a public health measure. Related activities such as room rentals as well as sports and cultural activities are also targeted by the closure.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How can teachers support students who are continuing to learn from home?
reference.section_content: A massive openonline course(In French only) is available, free of charge, for teachers who wish to improve their understanding of how technological tools can be used to provide support.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What is the plan for the progressive reopening of school daycares and educational childcare services?
reference.section_content: Educational childcare services Childcare services in all regions of QueÃÅbec, with the exception of theCommunauteÃÅ meÃÅtropolitaine de MontreÃÅal(In French only) (MontreÃÅal metropolitan community, CMM), will be progressively reopened for children of parents working in a job providing priority services. The exceptions made for the territory of the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community also apply for the territory of the regional county municipality of Joliette. Childcare services located in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette will reopen on Monday, June 1. They will also be reserved for the children of parents who are employed in jobs on thelist of essential services and commercial activities. For the weeks of May 18 and 25, emergency childcare services in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette will be reserved for the children of parents whoseemployment entitles them to emergency daycare services. Educational childcare services will return to full capacity at the end of June, health conditions permitting. School daycare services Starting May 11, school daycare services will resume their regular activities, with the exception of those located in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette. Emergency daycares will remain open in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette until June 30.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am a parent working in a job that entitles me to childcare services. How do I find a spot for my child who did not attend daycare before March 13?
reference.section_content: Parents who are entitled to emergency childcare services can use the La Place 0-5 website, which provides assistance to temporarily place children in daycares based on the capacity of educational childcare services.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do parents whose jobs are included in the list of essential priority services and activities need to provide proof of this when sending their children to childcare services?
reference.section_content: No.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: When will I have to resume paying childcare fees?
reference.section_content: Educational childcare services Parents who use the service must resume paying parental fees at a regular rate. The decision of whether or not to use the services is made on a voluntary basis. Any children who do not return to daycare immediately will not lose their place and will not be charged fees until the scheduled return to normal at the end of June. Parents are encouraged to contact their daycare to discuss the terms of their child‚Äôs return. School daycare services As of May 11 (May 25 in the MontreÃÅal metropolitan community and the regional county municipality of Joliette), since all school daycare services resume operations and may be used by children enrolled in the school on a voluntary basis, regular fees will apply.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Once individuals return to work, will grandparents under the age of 70 be able to help look after their grandchildren?
reference.section_content: The information published by the CNESST does not specifically forbid individuals aged 70 or older from continuing to a work. It could therefore be understood that individuals who are under the age of 70 and in good health may lend a helping hand and look after children to allow parents to return to work. Needless to say, the necessary health measures must be applied, especially with regard to physical distancing and proper hand hygiene for both the children and their grandparents. In addition, if the children experience symptoms associated with COVID-19, all contact between the children and the grandparents must be avoided.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it safe or are we allowed to babysit the children of friends or relatives to help them out?
reference.section_content: You are advised to limit your movements as much as possible and anyone who is not providing an essential service should stay at home. However, if someone needs a babysitter for their children and does not have access to day care or for whom the children cannot return to school, you may do so. The following conditions apply: you are in good health,no one has symptoms of fever, cough, difficulty breathing or sudden loss of smell without a stuffy nose, with or without loss of taste,no one has been told to self-isolate,no children in the family is going to school,no one in the home is at risk (e.g., chronically ill or 70 years of age or older). As far as possible, physical contact between children must be limited and they must be kept 2 metres apart. Regularly clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces and items, such as door handles, light switches, faucet handles, etc. If you must be in contact with children within 2 meters (e.g. infants), wear a face covering and wash your hands before and after taking the children. Clean bathrooms more frequently. Clean toys frequently, especially toys that children might put in their mouth. If you have been in close contact with children, change your clothes when you return home or when children leaves. Follow thehealth recommendations for everyone.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can an educational childcare centre refuse to accept a child?
reference.section_content: Yes, educational childcare centres must refuse: children whose parents do not work in a job on thelist of essential services and commercial activities, except for children of educational childcare personnelchildren who must be in isolation in accordance with thesafety measures for workers and children in elementary schools and daycare services during COVID-19.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should an educational childcare centre do if a child appears to show symptoms of COVID-19?
reference.section_content: Educational childcare services must follow thesafety measures for workers and children in elementary schools and daycare services during COVID-19. For more information, call 1‚Äê877‚Äê644‚Äê4545.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How many children can educational childcare services welcome, according to the different phases of the return to the normal occupancy rate?
reference.section_content: Access to childcare services is being increased gradually. Childcare centres are reopening at a limited occupancy rate and the return to normal occupancy will take place in several phases, based on the recommendations of the Direction geÃÅneÃÅrale de la santeÃÅ publique.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will hygiene and sanitation measures be taken in order to ensure everyone‚Äôs health and safety?
reference.section_content: Childcare services personnel must apply the infection control protocols they already use during respiratory infection season. Therefore: They must ensure that sick children are not admitted into the daycare and they must count on the parents‚Äô strict co-operation in this matter.They must isolate a sick child from other children and ask the parents to come and pick up the child as soon as possible. For more information: Safety measures for workers and children in elementary schools and daycare services during COVID-19Best practices guide(In French only)

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should be done if an educator shows symptoms?
reference.section_content: Refer to thesafety measures for workers and children in elementary schools and daycare services during COVID-19.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should be done if there is a case of COVID-19 at a daycare?
reference.section_content: If a child who attended the daycare tests positive for COVID-19, the first thing to do is to call your public health regional branch (if it has not already contacted you). The public health regional branch will investigate and take the necessary measures to evaluate and take charge of each of the sick child‚Äôs contacts (staff, children and close family).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which institutions are closed or open?
reference.section_content: College- and university-level teaching activities will continue at a distance for the Summer 2020 term, until September, except in the case of practical training that cannot be carried out remotely and that is necessary to enable students to continue their studies in order to graduate. Research activities in colleges, in the Centres colleÃÅgiaux de transfert de technologie and in universities may resume. Accordingly, research activities related to the health, science, agriculture, forestry and engineering sectors, as well as vital seasonal outdoor activities, the resumption of which is urgently awaited, may now begin. The resumption of activities in all other research sectors should also be considered if these sectors are directly related to the collective effort to relaunch the economy. Moreover, institutions of higher education may resume any activity they deem necessary and may authorize some of their employees to return to the workplace. Whenever possible, remote work must still be the preferred approach when resuming these activities. All of the above is conditional upon compliance with the guidelines issued by the competent authorities, namely the Direction de santeÃÅ publique, the CNESST and the IRSST.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Should students‚Äô internships be postponed?
reference.section_content: If internship settings have confirmed the continuation of the internship, the students‚Äô workplace respects the guidelines issued by the public health authority, and the students are able to complete the internship, for example, by working remotely, then internships are possible. However, students cannot be penalized for their inability to meet requirements.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are there any plans in place regarding students who expect to graduate from college or university?
reference.section_content: It is up to each institution to establish learning and evaluation procedures it deems appropriate in order to ensure that students develop the competencies required to complete their program of study and to graduate. Students should not be penalized for their inability to complete their program through alternative means developed by their institution.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can institutions implement a system to allow students and staff to retrieve their personal effects and school materials?
reference.section_content: Compiling of a list of students and materials Students may collect their personal effects once they have been invited to do so by the administration of the institution and in compliance with the hygiene measures issued by the Direction de SanteÃÅ publique. Access to educational institutions This is an exceptional procedure that aims to meet the most urgent needs of students, teachers and professors. The MinisteÃÄre will not establish specific categories; rather, it will call upon institutions to identify the persons concerned as well as the order of priority. Exceptionally, and for this purpose only, each institution must establish an adapted procedure that ensures compliance with physical distancing guidelines, particularly by tightly controlling the number of people who can access the institution‚Äôs premises. Anyone accessing a building on the institution‚Äôs premises must wash their hands upon entering and leaving. Students must be supervised when moving about the premises in order to minimize any risks. The administration must establish a precise schedule in order to control the number of people present at any given time and to ensure that necessary services are available to students and teachers with special needs. If necessary, the administration may contact its regional public health agency to obtain further information. These guidelines must be followed at all times: Handwashing is mandatory when entering a building.Physical distancing must be maintained and there must be no contact between individuals.Students cannot be accompanied by another person.Anyone experiencing flu-like symptoms must be excluded from this operation.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Have any measures been implemented for international students concerning administrative procedures related to the continuation of studies or internships, graduation and enrollment for subsequent terms?
reference.section_content: The modifications to the different administrative procedures announced for educational institutions apply to both QueÃÅbec and international students. It is recommended that any information that may be of interest on this page be consulted as it pertains to all students.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What financial assistance measures do international students have access to?
reference.section_content: International students will be entitled to theCanada Emergency Response Benefit(CERB) if they meet the program eligibility criteria, particularly: Have declared an income of at least $5000, earned in Canada or outside the country, during the last fiscal year or during the 12 months prior to their application. Applicants must be Canadian residents.Have stopped working in relation to the COVID-19 crisis, without having left their employment voluntarily. Thus, they are not eligible if they stopped working before the crisis began.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will international students receive financial assistance for the costs they incurred when returning to their country of origin?
reference.section_content: No measure is currently planned for this specific purpose. The repatriation of foreign nationals is usually the responsibility of their country of origin.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: In the event that the university term is extended, will international students have access to financial assistance given that they will have additional housing costs?
reference.section_content: No measure is currently planned for this specific purpose.No measure is currently planned for this specific purpose.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Could the expenses associated with alternative lodging for those who have to leave the university residences be reimbursed?
reference.section_content: No measure is currently planned for this specific purpose. However, the MinisteÃÄre has encouraged educational institutions to offer special support and possibly implement measures to help international students who may find themselves in a precarious situation.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What about international students who must return to their country of origin at the end of the term?
reference.section_content: International students will be able to leave Canada based on available flights or may choose to stay in Canada if they have yet to complete their studies, provided that their immigration documents are in order.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Should insitutions continue to process admission applications submitted by international students?
reference.section_content: Institutions are encouraged to continue processing all applications so as to not delay the subsequent steps required for international students to begin their studies at the chosen institution. International students must have a valid QueÃÅbec Acceptance Certificate (CAQ) and study permit when they begin their classes. To obtain these documents, students must have a proof of admission. Note that international students are not required to obtain a CAQ and a study permit prior to starting a program of study through distance education while they are not residing in Canada. However, they will need to obtain these documents before being authorized to enter the country to complete their program in person, as needed.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will international students be able to take courses during the Summer and Fall 2020 terms?
reference.section_content: International students can attend distance courses, just like QueÃÅbec students.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will specific measures be implemented in order to extend student visas for students and work permits for post-doctoral students?
reference.section_content: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) has not announced the automatic renewal of temporary residency permits. Students are asked to submit a request for renewal before the date on which their permit expires. If students meet this condition, they are granted ‚Äúimplied status,‚Äù meaning that their current temporary residency is maintained until a decision is made regarding their application. International students are requested not to go to border crossings in an attempt to renew their immigration documents. The most up-to-date information is usually published by thefederal government. The MinisteÃÄre de l‚ÄôImmigration, de la Francisation et de l‚ÄôInteÃÅgration (MIFI) is extending, until December 31, 2020, the minister‚Äôs consent for the duration of the stay in QueÃÅbec of international students whose QueÃÅbec Acceptance Certificate (CAQ) for studies expires as of April 30, 2020 and before December 31, 2020. This regulation applies to students whose CAQ had not already expired on April 30, 2020. Temporary residents must maintain valid temporary resident status at all times. The MinisteÃÄre de l‚ÄôImmigration, de la Francisation et de l‚ÄôinteÃÅgration (MIFI) continues to process applications for temporary selection.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will international students still be eligible for the Post-Graduation Work Permit Program (PGWPP) if institutions transition to distance education as a means to complete the current term during the COVID-19 crisis?
reference.section_content: Students who were already studying in Canada and whose courses were moved online due to the travel restrictions and public health measures introduced because of COVID-19 will not be penalized and will retain their eligibility for the PGWPP, including the length of the work permit to which they would be entitled. However, these students must continue at least 50 % of their program of study in Canada to be eligible for the PGWPP.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will international students be eligible for the PGWPP if they hold a study permit allowing them to continue their program of study during the summer term, but will be unable to enter Canada given the current travel restrictions?
reference.section_content: The IRCC has introduced a new temporary policy for students who currently hold a study permit or who were approved for a study permit for a program set to begin in May or June 2020, but who are unable to enter Canada due to the current travel restrictions. If courses of study are delivered online exceptionally because of COVID-19, the eligibility of these students for the Post-Graduation Work Permit Program (PGWPP) will not be affected. International students in this situation can begin their courses from outside Canada and complete up to 50% of their program from outside the country if they cannot travel to Canada earlier.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Some international students were enrolled to begin their program of study during the summer term, but were not or will not be able to obtain a CAQ and a study permit before the start of classes.What options do they have to continue their studies?
reference.section_content: international students are not required to obtain a QueÃÅbec Acceptance Certificate (CAQ) and a study permit to study through distance education. However, they will need to obtain these documents before being authorized to enter the country to complete their program in person, as needed. It is important to note that students whose study permits were issued no later than March 18, 2020, are exempt from thetravel restrictions in place in Canadaand are therefore allowed to enter the country. However, they must not be experiencing any symptoms prior to boarding their flight and must undergo a mandatory 14-day quarantine period upon their arrival.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are you an international student studying in QueÃÅbec? Do you have any questions on how to protect your health during the pandemic?
reference.section_content: For information on health protection, foreign nationals can refer to the Questions and answers about our services during the pandemic page on theReÃÅgie de l‚Äôassurance maladie du QueÃÅbec website, specifically the following sections: COVID-19: Information and screening ‚Äì What coverage does QueÃÅbec provide for COVID-19 screening and care?Foreign workers and students in QueÃÅbec: health insurance coverage

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Extending the duration of the QueÃÅbec Acceptance Certificate (CAQ) for studies
reference.section_content: The MinisteÃÄre de l‚ÄôImmigration, de la Francisation et de l‚ÄôInteÃÅgration (MIFI) is extending, until December 31, 2020, the minister‚Äôs consent for the duration of the stay in QueÃÅbec of international students whose QueÃÅbec Acceptance Certificate (CAQ) for studies expires as of April 30, 2020 and before December 31, 2020. This regulation applies to students whose CAQ had not already expired on April 30, 2020. This decision is intended to facilitate the steps that must be taken by inernational students who were in the process of completing their study program but who must extend their stay in QueÃÅbec due to the current health state of emergency and the temporary interruption of their courses. These students can therefore submit an application to the federal government as soon as possible to have their study permit extended without having to include a new CAQ, which will allow them to maintain valid temporary residence status and to complete their study program when their courses resume.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will students have to pay fees for extending their CAQ?
reference.section_content: No, international students will not have to pay any fees for extending their CAQ, since the required fees were already paid when they submitted their application for the CAQ that they obtained.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What about students who would like to continue their studies after December 31, 2020?
reference.section_content: International students who would like to extend their stay in QueÃÅbec for studies beyond December 31, 2020, in order to complete a study program or to begin a new program in the fall 2020 semester, must submit a new application for a CAQ for studies to the MIFI and a new application for a study permit to the federal government. In all cases, students should start the required immigration procedures at least three months before their current authorization for studies expires.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What happens to internaional students whose semester has been interrupted and who were waiting for their diploma in order to submit an application for the PEQ?
reference.section_content: International students who have earned their degree can submit an application for permanent selection under the PEQ if they have been awarded, by an educational institution in QueÃÅbec, within three years of the date of submission of their application, one of the following: a university diploma attesting to a bachelor‚Äôs, a master‚Äôs or a doctoral degreea college diploma for technical studies or a vocational diploma at the secondary level, with or without attestation of vocational specialization, obtained consecutively, attesting to 1800 hours or more of consecutive study and leading to a trade The MinisteÃÄre accepts attestations of successful completion of a study program as well as a final transcripts issued by the registrar of the educational institution. Since the programs admissible under the PEQ must have a minimum duration of 1800 hours, these graduates can obtain a three-year post-graduation work permit. The duration of this permit gives them all the time they need to submit an application for permanent selection under the PEQ as graduates or even as temporary foreign workers.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will study permits for international students who are already in QueÃÅbec be automatically renewed?
reference.section_content: The federal government is responsible for issuing study permits. If you have any questions about study permits, please visitImmigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada‚Äôs website.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will the Explore program be maintained?
reference.section_content: All Explore 2020 spring and summer sessions have been cancelled.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What impact will lengthening the closure of educational institutions have on student financial assistance?
reference.section_content: Financial assistance will continue to be available for students whose period of studies may be lengthened.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
