section_headers: What adjustments will be made to the student financial assistance program in response to the crisis?
reference.section_content: For the moment, the student financial assistance program has not been modified. Payments will continue to be issued.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can the assistance paid out as part of the student financial assistance program be quickly recalculated, to take into consideration the reduced income of recipients as a result of the current economic instability?
reference.section_content: The income taken into account when calculating the 2019-2020 financial assistance is that of the 2019 calendar year. For that reason, any fluctuations in the students‚Äô income in 2020 are not considered for 2019-2020. In some cases, they may, however, affect the calculations for 2020-2021. The government has announced that it will be postponing repayment of any loans incurred under the Loans and Bursaries Program and the Loans Program for Part-Time Studies for a period of six months.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will financial assistance be adapted in order to support students whose financial situation has changed (e.g. caring for a child or losing their job)?
reference.section_content: The Loans and Bursaries Program already accounts for the financial needs of people who are caring for children. Students who have lost their jobs due to the current situation may apply for the Canada Emergency Response Benefit.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Since the federal government has announced increases to bursaries in 2020-2021, and QueÃÅbec has its own system for managing student financial assistance, will more money be invested in this program?
reference.section_content: The Minister of Education and Higher Education is currently studying the best ways to increase the amount of financial assistance awarded to students in QueÃÅbec and is collaborating with the federal government to ensure financing. Announcements to student associations are planned in the coming weeks to prepare for a rollout in Fall 2020.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do I have to continue paying my student loan?
reference.section_content: No, the government has announced that repayments of all loans contracted under the Loans and Bursaries Program and the Loans for Part-Time Studies Program are postponed for a period of six months. The government will pay the interest. No payments are expected during this period. You do not have to take any steps or provide any proof to benefit from this exceptional measure, since it applies automatically to anyone who has incurred a debt with Aide financieÃÄre aux eÃÅtudes.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do I have to pay interest on my student loan during this period?
reference.section_content: No. The government will pay the interest. Students are not required to make any payments during this period.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I still make loan repayments?
reference.section_content: Yes. Contact your financial institution. They will tell you what steps to follow.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do I have to apply to have my repayment postponed?
reference.section_content: No. The government has made arrangements with all partner financial institutions to automatically postpone the repayment plan. People who have contracted student loans do not have to take any action.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will my monthly payments change after the six-month postponement period is over?
reference.section_content: No. Your financial institution will automatically extend the amortization period for your loan by six months and your monthly payments will remain the same.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am currently repaying my loan directly to the MinisteÃÄre de l'EÃÅducation et de l'Enseignement supeÃÅrieur. Does this announcement apply to me?
reference.section_content: Yes. This measure applies to all outstanding amounts, whether owed to a financial institution or in collection with Aide financieÃÄre aux eÃÅtudes.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am currently using the Deferred Payment Plan. How will this postponement of repayments change my situation?
reference.section_content: For the next six months, you will not be required to make repayments of your student loan. Your Deferred Payment Plan is also suspended for six months. After this postponement ends, your Deferred Payment Plan will continue for the rest of the time remaining in it.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will these six months be included in the eligibility period for the Deferred Payment Plan?
reference.section_content: No. This postponement is not included in the 60months of eligibility for the Deferred Payment Plan.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Does this measure apply to all my student loans?
reference.section_content: No. This postponement applies only to student loans contracted under a program offered by the Aide financieÃÄre aux eÃÅtudes department of the MinisteÃÄre de l‚ÄôEÃÅducation et de l‚ÄôEnseignement supeÃÅrieur. If you have questions about lines of credit and other student loans offered by your financial institution, please contact the staff there directly.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What instructions apply to children in shared custody?
reference.section_content: There is no single response. We are appealing to the parents‚Äô collaboration and good judgment. When a change of custody seems necessary, ensure that each family has abided by the hygiene instructions issued by public health authorities. Court judgments and orders must also be observed. For any specific situation, you can call theClinique d‚Äôassistance juridique COVID-19established by theMinisteÃÄre de la Justice du QueÃÅbecand theBarreau du QueÃÅbecat1-866-699-9729(toll free).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I‚Äôm worried about COVID-19 transmission risks arising from changes of custody of my child.
reference.section_content: Several situations may occur during this pandemic: One of the parents tests positive for COVID-19 or is experiencing symptoms;Someone in the family‚Äôs circle tests positive for COVID-19 or is experiencing symptoms;The child tests positive for COVID-19 or is experiencing symptoms;One of the parents, the child or someone in the family‚Äôs circle has to self-isolate after a trip abroad. In these cases, 14-day self-isolation is required to contain the spread of the virus. During this period, the child will not be able to move from one home to another if someone on one side or the other is in self-isolation. The goal is to contain the spread of the virus. If you‚Äôre worried about the precautionary measures taken by the other parent but none of the above situations apply, it‚Äôs best to discuss among yourselves to attempt to remedy the situation.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Should I comply with the custody and access order?
reference.section_content: Previous agreements, whether a custody or access order or an agreement between the parents, for instance following family mediation, should be complied with to the greatest extent possible. However, given the current situation, everyone should use common sense and follow the public health recommendations. Everyone has a part to play in reducing the spread of the virus and should collaborate and follow the health recommendations. This also applies to separated parents and families where the child may have to move from one household to another.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What can I do if I can‚Äôt come to an agreement with my ex?
reference.section_content: Children have essential needs, which can include having access to both parents and being sheltered from tension between parents. If there is a disagreement, parents can call on a family mediator to facilitate discussion and work on resolving the conflict. Many mediators work remotely, which helps avoid physical contact and maintain distancing measures. Some mediation sessions can even be free depending on your situation. For more information about mediation, mediation costs or to find a mediator, visit the following section in the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice‚Äôs website: ¬´Family mediation - Negotiating a fair agreement¬ª.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How can I limit inconveniences for my child if it becomes hard to respect the usual custody rights?
reference.section_content: If a child needs both parents, we recommend making communication possible through technological means (Skype, Facetime, etc.) for the duration of the crisis.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: We have joint custody, which means moving from one household to another throughout the week. Should we maintain this system?
reference.section_content: The custody or access order should be complied with as much as possible. However, during this pandemic, you can try to work out new terms with the other parent to minimize travel.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: We live in different regions. Should we still proceed with the change of custody?
reference.section_content: The custody or access order should be complied with as much as possible. However, during this pandemic, people are asked to limit travel between regions as much as possible. You can try to work out new terms with the other parent to minimize travel and agree to maintain contact through technological means. If the change of custody involves travel to a health region where travel restrictions have been implemented, the parent must explain to the police officers that he or she is carrying out a change of custody or exercising an access right. Travel should be permitted whether the custody or access right was granted by Court order or pursuant to an agreement. You can call on a family mediator to facilitate discussion and work on reaching an agreement. Many mediators work remotely, which helps avoid contact. You can find alist of accredited mediatorson the MJQ‚Äôs website.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I‚Äôm worried because my ex-spouse works in healthcare.
reference.section_content: he healthcare system is taking the necessary measures to protect its staff.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I‚Äôm worried because my ex-spouse takes public transit.
reference.section_content: Public transit services are still running and are essential for people such as healthcare and social service workers to commute to their jobs. QueÃÅbec transit companies have increased the maintenance frequency of their vehicles and installations. Commuters are still encouraged to follow health recommendations and keep two metres apart whenever possible. Commuters are also encouraged to adjust their commuting schedule if possible to reduce crowding during peak hours.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How can I get legal advice for my specific situation?
reference.section_content: The COVID-19 legal aid clinic is a free legal aid hotline for citizens who have questions about their rights and obligations in the context of the ongoing pandemic. Your questions will be answered by lawyers specializing in a broad range of fields, including family law: 1 866 699-9729(toll-free)418 838-6415(National Capital)514 789-2755(MontreÃÅal)819 303-4080(Gatineau)

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How are decisions about a child‚Äôs education made?
reference.section_content: Both parents have parental authority unless they have been deprived of parental rights. There are two types of decisions: important decisions and everyday decisions. Important decisionsare those that concern the child‚Äôs health (e.g., medical care), choice of school, religion, etc. Parents must consult each other before making important decisions affecting their child‚Äôs life, regardless of the custody type. These decisions must be made by both parents. In case of a disagreement, the issue is decided by the court. Everyday decisionsare made by the parent with whom the child is staying that day. They include things like bedtime hours, food and participation in school activities. Allowing a child to go back to school for the remainder of the year in the context of the pandemic is an important decision that must be made by both parents. It is an important decision given the health risks that can arise from the child continuing to see both parents in two different environments. For instance, fear of contagion can be warranted for a parent who has a pre-existing medical condition. Sending a child to school in this context could prevent a parent with a medical condition from exercising their custody rights. Both parents must therefore agree on whether their child should return to school during the public health emergency.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What if parents can‚Äôt agree on this issue?
reference.section_content: Parents who can‚Äôt come to an agreement could seek the help of a family mediator. For more information about mediation, mediation costs or to find a mediator, please visit theFamily mediation - Negotiating a fair agreementpage on the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice‚Äôs website. Alternatively, as with other issues relating to important decisions that fall under parental authority, the parents could take their disagreement to court.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am a debtor of child support and no longer have an income or have a reduced income. Do I still have to comply with the child support order?
reference.section_content: Parents must comply with a child support order or an agreement between parents, for instance in family mediation. However, given the current situation, the parents‚Äô annual income may have changed, which could affect the amount of child support payable. Child support is normally determined based on the following: annual income of each parent;number of children;custody time;certain additional expenses to meet a child‚Äôs needs, if any. A change in one of these elements can affect the child support payable. Child support payments should be maintained insofar as possible. The current situation can affect both parents. Suspending child support collection or payments may not be the best solution at it will deprive the child of amounts required to meet its essential needs.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I pay spousal support and no longer have an income or have a reduced income. Do I still have to comply with the support order?
reference.section_content: Yes, you must comply with a child support order or an agreement to that effect. Spousal support is not calculated based on a scale the way child support is. Support payments should be maintained insofar as possible. You can try to reach an agreement with your ex-spouse. Certain mediation sessions may be free depending on your situation. For more information about mediation, mediation costs or to find a mediator, please visit thesection on mediation in the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice website. A judgment is necessary to modify the support payments collected by Revenu QueÃÅbec. You can obtain it by using theHomologation Assistance Service (HAS). The modified judgment will be transmitted to Revenu QueÃÅbec, which will then adjust the amount collected and paid. Recipients of last resort assistance who are creditors of support must inform the MinisteÃÄre du Travail, de l‚ÄôEmploi et de la SolidariteÃÅ Sociale whether they wish to reach an agreement to cancel, reduce or suspend the support payments. In the context of an HAS application, the creditor who receives last resort assistance must send a support application notice at least 10 days before submitting the agreement. All proceedings before the Superior Court instituted by a party who receives last resort assistance to cancel, reduce or suspend support payments must be notified to the Attorney General of QueÃÅbec.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: The support payments I make are collected by Revenu QueÃÅbec. Why can‚Äôt Revenu QueÃÅbec stop collecting these payments during the pandemic?
reference.section_content: Revenu QueÃÅbec is enforcing a judgment rendered by the court. To change the amount it collects, Revenu QueÃÅbec must receive a new judgment setting out a new support amount.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: If there is a change to one of the elements taken into account when calculating support payments, should I hurry to apply for a review?
reference.section_content: It is best to proceed with caution, primarily because: the changes to parents‚Äô income due to the COVID-19 pandemic are temporary;parents‚Äô medium and long-term income is hard to establish for the time being;according to the rules governing support, the parents‚Äô foreseeable income for the next 12 months as well as their assets can be taken into consideration. The QueÃÅbec and Canadian governments are taking various measures to minimize the impact of the pandemic on each individual‚Äôs financial situation. TheChild Support Payments Calculation Toolis available to help you estimate child support payments you must make or will receive based on your individual situation. The interactive form costs nothing to use, and is simple and quick to complete. Simply enter your data, and the calculation will be carried out automatically. Before adjusting the amount of child support payable, if you‚Äôve lost your job, for instance, it would be best to know the amounts to which you will be entitled in order to determine your income. The child support payment amount can also include costs related to children, for example daycare costs. Since parents will not have to cover these costs during the pandemic whether or not they are entitled to emergency daycare services, they may be taken into account when reviewing the support payable, but only for the period during which these fees are waived. Educational childcare services will be free for parents who are essential service workers, which entitles them to emergency daycare services. Parents‚Äô contributions will be covered by the MinisteÃÄre de la Famille. Parents who can no longer use educational childcare services during the public health emergency will no longer have to pay childcare costs. For more information, visit theMinisteÃÄre de la Famille‚Äôs website

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I try to reach an agreement with my ex-spouse to modify the support amount?
reference.section_content: You can try to reach an agreement with your ex-spouse by using theChild Support Payments Calculation Tool. Even during the COVID-19 pandemic, parents who have information about their income can call on a family mediator to facilitate discussion and work on reaching an agreement. Many mediators work remotely, which helps avoid direct contact between people. Certain mediation sessions may be free depending on your situation. For more information about mediation, mediation costs or to find a mediator, please visit thesection on mediation in the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice website. A judgment is necessary to modify the support payments collected by Revenu QueÃÅbec. You can obtain it by using theHomologation Assistance Service (HAS)The modified judgment will be transmitted to Revenu QueÃÅbec, which will then adjust the amount collected and paid. Recipients of last resort assistance who are creditors of support must inform the MinisteÃÄre du Travail, de l‚ÄôEmploi et de la SolidariteÃÅ Sociale whether they wish to reach an agreement to cancel, reduce or suspend the support payments. In the context of an HAS application, the creditor who receives last resort assistance must send a support application notice at least 10 days before submitting the agreement. All proceedings before the Superior Court instituted by a party who receives last resort assistance to cancel, reduce or suspend support payments must be notified to the Attorney General of QueÃÅbec. Once your financial situation has stabilized, this amount must be reviewed as it is parents‚Äô responsibility to make sure that the support payments are up to date based on both parents‚Äô income.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should I do if my financial situation is too difficult and I can‚Äôt reach an agreement with my ex-spouse?
reference.section_content: In this case, an application can be brought before the Superior Court.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What income is used when determining child support?
reference.section_content: For this calculation, annual income is income from all sources and includes: wages, salaries and other remuneration;net income from the operation of a business or self-employment;employment insurance and parental insurance benefits;personal support payments from another person;interest, taxable amounts of dividends and other investment income;net rental income;benefits paid under other legislation as part of a pension or compensation plan;other income. Annual income includes all the income received by each parent, except the following amounts, which are not considered to be annual income and therefore are not used in calculating disposable income: family-related government transfers (child assistance payments, Canada Child Benefit (CCB), etc.);amounts received under the Work Premium program;last resort financial assistance (welfare) benefits;amounts granted under a financial assistance program for education expenses managed by the MinisteÃÄre de l‚ÄôEÃÅducation, du Loisir et du Sport.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Why is it hard to determine or review child support payments during the COVID-19 pandemic?
reference.section_content: Child support is determined based on both parents‚Äô income. In the Child Support Determination Form, parents must enter their income for the current year or, if applicable, their foreseeable income for the next 12 months. However, during this pandemic, many parents find it hard to foresee their income for the next 12 months. The Canadian government has announced various measures to help individuals obtain financial assistance quickly. They include the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) and the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy for businesses. For more information on these measures, seeCanada‚Äôs COVID-19 Economic Response Plan.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: If I wait for my income situation to stabilize before asking for a support payment modification, can my income reduction during the pandemic be taken into account?
reference.section_content: Yes, once your income situation has stabilized, it will be possible to ask for a support payment review for the period during which your income was reduced. If the payments are collected by Revenu QueÃÅbec, a judgment that clearly indicates the periods covered by the adjustment must be obtained. For instance, support payments will be reduced for a few months before returning to normal. You can use theHomologation Assistance Service (HAS)to obtain this judgment following an agreement with your ex-spouse or family mediation.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Where can I find general information about family law?
reference.section_content: You can find information on the following websites: MinisteÃÄre de la JusticeFamily mediation - Negotiating a fair agreementChildren: a joint responsibility¬´Separation and divorce¬ª sectionEÃÅducaloi : ¬´Separation and divorce¬ª section. You can call Info-Social 811 (free psychosocial hotline open 24/7): Call Info-Social 811 if you are experiencing: stress, anxiety;prolonged emotional reactions (frequent crying, irritability, etc.);feelings of panic;overwhelming and frightening thoughts that won‚Äôt go away;social repercussions from the illness. Psychosocial intervention professionals will provide support and give you advice and information based on your needs.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What should I do with my refundable containers?
reference.section_content: If you want to return your refundable containers, please be advised that return-refund activities resume gradually. Collection and recovery operations can be organized by retailers in outdoor areas in their parking lots, when possible. Temporary measures for returning containers  have been  into effect sinceMay 18.  Locations, collection dates, and criteria to observe for facilitating container returns are available on theResumption of activities(French) page. Citizens are asked to cooperate to prevent these containers from ending up in the trash.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I take my bulky items and other debris to an ecocentre or other drop-off site?
reference.section_content: Put off your visits to the ecocentre or other drop-off site until later. In the meantime, avoid putting the materials or items in the trash.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on education and families during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do I need to take special protective measures with protective equipment and tissues?
reference.section_content: At home, used tissues, gloves, masks, disposable wipes, and other protective products or cleaners that are potentially contaminated should be placed in a sealed bag and then in a closed waste container. These materials should not be placed in recycling or organic collection bins or flushed down the toilet. Away from home, if you use tissues, gloves, masks, wipes or other protective products or cleaners, please throw them in the trash after you have finished using them or take them home and dispose of them properly.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What happens with scheduled hearings?
reference.section_content: The Court of QueÃÅbec and the Superior Court have decided to suspend their activities, while maintaining essential services. See thelist of urgent judicial activities that are maintained;See theinstructions of the Court of QueÃÅbec; For hearings that are not considered urgent: For civil proceedings (including small claims), you will receive a new notice of hearing.For penal proceedings (for example, for infractions of the Highway Safety Code), you will receive a new notice of hearing.For criminal trials, please contact your lawyer, if you are represented, or contact the client contact centre directly at 1 866 536-5140.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How can I find out what happens to my personal situation?
reference.section_content: Please refer to the first question to find out if your type of case will still be heard by the court. If you are represented, please contact your lawyer for more information. Otherwise, please contact the client contact centre directly at 1 866 536-5140.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: In the event of a cancellation, do I have to take any action?
reference.section_content: No, you do not have to do anything. For criminal trials, please contact your lawyer, if you are represented, or contact the client contact centre directly at 1-866-536-5140. For all other proceedings, if you are represented by a lawyer, the latter will be able to provide you with the necessary information. If you are representing yourself, you will be notified by mail in the next few weeks of a new hearing date.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I have received a jury summons. Do I have to report for jury duty?
reference.section_content: No, trials with a jury are cancelled until further notice. You may be summoned again in the future.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What about administrative tribunals and other bodies holding hearings?
reference.section_content: Generally speaking, only urgent proceedings will proceed. The same rules of access to courthouses apply to administrative tribunals and other bodies holding hearings. For more information on administrative tribunals and other bodies holding hearings, please see their website or contact them directly: Bureau des preÃÅsidents des conseils de discipline des ordres professionnelsComiteÃÅ de deÃÅontologie policieÃÄreCommission d'acceÃÄs aÃÄ l'information du QueÃÅbecCommission de la fonction publiqueCommission de protection du territoire agricole du QueÃÅbecCommission des transports du QueÃÅbecCommission municipale du QueÃÅbecReÃÅgie de l'eÃÅnergieReÃÅgie des alcools, des courses et des jeuxReÃÅgie des marcheÃÅs agricoles et alimentaires du QueÃÅbecReÃÅgie du baÃÇtiment du QueÃÅbecReÃÅgie du logementTribunal administratif des marcheÃÅs financiersTribunal administratif du QueÃÅbecTribunal administratif du travail

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which time limits are suspended for civil proceedings?
reference.section_content: The time limits for extinctive prescription and forfeiture in civil matters are suspended until the declaration of a public health emergency expires. The time limits for civil proceedings are also suspended during this period, except for cases deemed urgent by the courts.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which time limits are suspended for penal proceedings?
reference.section_content: Except for cases deemed urgent by the courts, the following time limits set out in the Code of Penal Procedure (chapter C  25.1) are suspended until the declaration of a public health emergency expires: to retain the thing seized or the proceeds of the sale thereof and to obtain an extension of the retention period (articles 132 and 133);to transmit a plea of guilty or not guilty after service of a statement of offence (article 160);to file an application for revocation of a judgment rendered by default (article 252);to bring an appeal before the Superior Court (article 271);to file a written appearance in the Superior Court (article 274);to apply for an appeal by way of a new hearing (article 282);to apply for leave to appeal before the Court of Appeal (article 296);to file a written appearance in the Court of Appeal (article 303);to file a factum at the office of the Court of Appeal together with proof of its service (articles 304 and 305);to pay a sum due to the collector (article 322);to carry out compensatory work (article 338). The time limits to retain the thing seized or the proceeds of the sale thereof and to obtain an extension of the retention period provided under sections 40.4 and 40.7 of the Tax Administration Act (chapter A-6.002) are also suspended during this period. Notwithstanding articles 96 and 103 of the Code of Penal Procedure, any search may be authorized by a telewarrant.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which time limits are suspended for administrative proceedings?
reference.section_content: The time limits for bringing proceedings relating to matters heard by the following bodies, excluding matters deemed urgent by their presidents or members the presidents designate for that purpose, are suspended until the declaration of a public health emergency expires: the Administrative Tribunal of QueÃÅbec;the Administrative Labour Tribunal;the Financial Markets Administrative Tribunal;the Commission de la fonction publique;the Commission d‚ÄôacceÃÄs aÃÄ l‚Äôinformation (adjudication division); However, this does not apply to proceedings relating to applications for certification provided under section 22 of the Labour Code (chapter C-27). Additionally, the time limit to lodge a complaint regarding police ethics provided under section 150 of the Police Act (chapter P-13.1) is suspended until the declaration of a public health emergency expires. Concerning matters under the jurisdiction of: the ComiteÃÅ de deÃÅontologie policieÃÄre;the Commission municipale du QueÃÅbec;the Commission des transports du QueÃÅbec;the ReÃÅgie des alcools, des courses et des jeux;the ReÃÅgie des marcheÃÅs agricoles et alimentaires du QueÃÅbec;time limits are suspended for:applying for the renewal of a permit or other similar authorization;paying fees or charges;making submissions;applying for review of a decision. However, this does not apply to the periodic review of a recognition under section 243.19 of the Act respecting municipal taxation (chapter F-2.1).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Am I allowed to go to a courthouse?
reference.section_content: Since Monday, March 16, access to all courthouses is limited to those who are summoned to a hearing or trial or those who need a service provided at a courthouse. Anyone else is asked not to go to any courthouse in QueÃÅbec.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I accompany a family member or friend or attend their trial or hearing?
reference.section_content: Generally speaking, it is not possible. However, in some cases, the judge may allow a person to attend a hearing.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I access the courthouse to obtain the services of the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice or another agency located there?
reference.section_content: Yes, but for services that are considered urgent. As a precaution, if you need to file a proceeding, we ask that you do so by mail for non-urgent proceedings. However, please note that the legal time limits within which civil proceedings must be filed are suspended until the declaration of a state of health emergency expires. To file an application or a response with the Small Claims Division of the Court of QueÃÅbec, you can go online and do so using theonline form. For services relating to the Bureau des infractions et amendes, you can make a payment online atwww.amendes.qc.caor by telephone at 1 877 263-6337 (AMENDES). For more information, please contact an agent of the Bureau des infractions et amendes at the same telephone number. For registers, such as the register of personal and movable real rights, most of the transactions can be done by mail or online athttps://www.justice.gouv.qc.ca/en/programs-and-services/registers.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am a journalist. Am I allowed to enter the courthouse and attend hearings?
reference.section_content: In the context of the public health emergency, journalists are only allowed access to courthouses to attend hearings. Non-urgent consultation of files and use of public computers at a courthouse office are forbidden as they may spread infection. The court ledger can be consultedonline through the services provided by the SOQUIJ.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do these rules apply to all courts or only to those located in a courthouse?
reference.section_content: The access restrictions apply to all courthouses and service points in QueÃÅbec, all municipal courts and all administrative tribunals and public administration agencies that hold hearings.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Until when will the measures in place apply?
reference.section_content: They apply until further notice.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Marriages and civil unions: what services are maintained?
reference.section_content: Ceremonies already scheduled will take place. Only the spouses and the witnesses will be admitted. However, if you would like to postpone your ceremony, please contact the client contact centre at 1 866 536-5140. If no ceremony has been scheduled, only ceremonies for humanitarian reasons can be planned.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I have an interview at the small claims court. What will happen?
reference.section_content: It is cancelled. You will be contacted to set a new date. You can alsouse the online service to submit your request. Please note that the legal time limits within which civil proceedings must be filed are suspended until the declaration of a state of health emergency expires.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I have to file an application or response with the small claims court. Can I do so?
reference.section_content: You can do so online directly on our website using theonline formor by mail. Please note that the legal time limits within which civil proceedings must be filed are suspended until the declaration of a state of health emergency expires.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I have to file a non-contentious proceeding (protective supervision, will probation, etc.). Can I do so?
reference.section_content: You may file these types of applications at the courthouse if it is urgent. Otherwise, we ask that you submit your documents by mail, making sure to include your contact information so that the clerk can get in touch with you regarding fee payment.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I would like to open a voluntary deposit file or make a deposit in my file. Can I do so?
reference.section_content: Yes, these services are maintained. However, you will have to make an appointment by calling the client contact centre at 1 866 536-5140. The suspension of time limits announced by the Minister of Justice due to the public health emergency also applies to voluntary deposits. People who do not make a deposit during the public health emergency will not lose the benefit of voluntary deposit.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I would like to pay a fine or make payment arrangements or discuss my file with a fine collector. Can I do so?
reference.section_content: Yes. For services relating to the Bureau des infractions et amendes (BIA), you can contact a BIA agent at 1 877 263-6337 (AMENDES). You can also make a payment online atwww.amendes.qc.caor by telephone at 1 877 263-6337 (AMENDES).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I would like to apply for a restricted licence or a release from seizure of a road vehicle. What can I do?
reference.section_content: Come to the courthouse with the form. Forms are available in theMinisteÃÄre de la Justice documentation center. It is advisable that you fill out the form in advance.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Will the counter of the Personal and Movable Real Rights Registry Office at the MontreÃÅal courthouse remain open?
reference.section_content: Yes, the counter remains accessible, but we encourage you to use our online services atwww.rdprm.gouv.qc.ca.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which in-person payment methods are accepted during the public health emergency?
reference.section_content: The usual payment methods are accepted. However, as we try to avoid contact with cash to limit the spread of the virus, we highly recommend paying by debit or credit card. Payments can still be made in cash, but we ask that you pay with exact change if possible. Our staff will explain how to make the payment safely.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: If I cannot file a civil proceeding, will I forfeit my rights?
reference.section_content: Please note that the legal time limits within which civil proceedings must be filed are suspended until the declaration of a state of health emergency expires. Therefore, you will not forfeit your rights.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Where can I get legal advice with respect to the exceptional measures that have been put in place?
reference.section_content: If you are represented by a lawyer, please contact him or her. The MinisteÃÄre de la Justice cannot provide legal advice. To access free legal information, support and referral services, please contact a jurist from your local Community Justice Center:www.justicedeproximite.qc.ca. A telephone hotline offering free legal assistance is already in operation. You can get answers to questions about your rights and obligations during the current pandemic. The hotline is available from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday to Friday, and is staffed by legal experts throughout QueÃÅbec who can quickly respond to your legal concerns. To reach the COVID-19 legal aid clinic: 1 866 699-9729 (toll free)418 838-6415 (Capitale-Nationale region)514 789-2755 (MontreÃÅal)819 303-4080 (Gatineau) Important: If your question concerns the services provided by the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice, in particular in courthouses, you should contact the Centre de communication avec la clienteÃÄle (CCC) at 1 866 536-5140. Before calling the hotline or the CCC, please refer to the ‚ÄúQuestions and answers‚Äù below.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible to be sworn in remotely?
reference.section_content: Yes. We invite you to visitAlex's Blog on the subject(In French). Adocument on the subjectis available (In French).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How does the suspension of time limits applies to voluntary deposits?
reference.section_content: Time limits are suspended starting March 15, 2020, and will remain suspended for the duration of the public health emergency. This means that time limits are frozen during this period and will begin to run again once the public health emergency is lifted.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Do I have to continue paying my voluntary deposit amounts during the public health emergency?
reference.section_content: In principle, you are required to respect your obligations and pay the amounts due pursuant to your voluntary deposit undertaking. However, we ask that you refrain from going to a Quebec courthouse in person as access to the premises is restricted. You may temporarilymake your payment by personal chequepayable to the Minister of Finance. Please write your file number on your cheque and make sure your name and contact information are written legibly on your cheque or on a separate sheet of paper included with your cheque. The cheque must be mailed to the courthouse where your file was opened.Courthouse addressescan be found on the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice‚Äôs website atwww.justice.gouv.qc.ca/en/join-us/find-a-courthouse/.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I received a Notice of Default for failing to make a payment or failing to update my information. What should I do in order not to lose the protection of voluntary deposit?
reference.section_content: The 30-day time limit to remedy your default is suspended for the duration of the public health emergency. This gives you more time to pay the amounts due (or ask the clerk for an extension) or to do a yearly update of your information. For instance, if you had 5 days left to remedy your default when the public health emergency was declared, you will have 5 days left to do so once it is lifted. If the public health emergency was already in effect when you received the notice, you will have 30 days to remedy your default once the public health emergency is lifted. However, you should remedy your default as soon as possible after the public health emergency is lifted.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I lost my job or have a reduced income. What should I do?
reference.section_content: You must report any change in your situation or information within 10 days following the change. However, this time limit is suspended for the duration of the public health emergency, which gives you more time to notify the clerk of these changes. We recommend that you act promptly since these changes often impact the amounts due, which could be beneficial for you. To notify the office of the Court of a change in your situation, please fill out the ‚ÄúDeclaration by Voluntary Deposit Debtor (SJ-1086)‚Äù form on the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice‚Äôs website. Then mail it to thecourthouse where your file was opened.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I received a Notice of full payment of claims, what should I do to not lose the right to contest within the allotted time?
reference.section_content: The contestation period set out in article 776(4) of the Code of Civil Procedure is suspended by order of the Minister of Justice (2020-4251). Accordingly, the court clerk can only give an acquittance once the 15-day period has expired after the public health emergency is lifted.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can lawyers access courthouses?
reference.section_content: Yes, but we ask that you refrain from doing so unless your visit to the courthouse cannot be postponed.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can lawyers use the rooms at the courthouse for legal procedures (e.g.: discoveries)?
reference.section_content: No.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What services will no longer be offered by the courthouse offices?
reference.section_content: Courthouse offices remain open. However, we ask that you refrain from going to a courthouse office unless it is urgent. As a precaution, if you need to file a proceeding, we ask that you do so by mail for non-urgent proceedings. Make sure to include your contact information so that the clerk can get in touch with you regarding fee payment. Note that time limits for extinctive prescription and forfeiture in civil matters are suspended until the declaration of a public health emergency expires. The time limits for civil proceedings are also suspended during this period, except for cases deemed urgent by the courts.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible to file proceedings?
reference.section_content: As a precaution, we ask that you file non-urgent proceedings by mail. Make sure to include your contact information so that the clerk can get in touch with you regarding fee payment.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Est-il possible d'obtenir une copie de documents se trouvant dans un dossier judiciaire?
reference.section_content: Dans le contexte actuel, seul le traitement des demandes de copies relatives aux proceÃÅdures jugeÃÅes urgentes sera assureÃÅ. Si votre demande de copie est relative aÃÄ une proceÃÅdure urgente, celle-ci peut eÃÇtre preÃÅsenteÃÅe en vous adressant au greffe du palais de justice concerneÃÅ, par courriel ou teÃÅleÃÅcopieur. Si la demande de copie concerne un document ordinaire, le retour sera effectueÃÅ par courriel. Concernant une demande de copie conforme, le retour sera effectueÃÅ par envoi postal.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are all time limits determined in the case protocol for civil matters suspended?
reference.section_content: Yes, all time limits for civil proceedings are suspended since March 15, 2020, in accordance withMinisterial Order 4251 published March 15, 2020, except for cases deemed urgent by the courts.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are time limits for trial readiness in civil matters automatically suspended?
reference.section_content: Yes, all time limits for civil proceedings are suspended since March 15, 2020, in accordance withMinisterial Order 4251 published March 15, 2020, except for cases deemed urgent by the courts.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Which hearings are maintained in administrative tribunals and other bodies holding hearings?
reference.section_content: Generally speaking, only urgent proceedings will proceed. The same rules of access to courthouses apply to administrative tribunals and other bodies holding hearings. For more information on administrative tribunals and other bodies holding hearings, please see their website or contact them directly: Bureau des preÃÅsidents des conseils de discipline des ordres professionnelsComiteÃÅ de deÃÅontologie policieÃÄreCommission d'acceÃÄs aÃÄ l'information du QueÃÅbecCommission de la fonction publiqueCommission de protection du territoire agricole du QueÃÅbecCommission des transports du QueÃÅbecCommission municipale du QueÃÅbecReÃÅgie de l'eÃÅnergieReÃÅgie des alcools, des courses et des jeuxReÃÅgie des marcheÃÅs agricoles et alimentaires du QueÃÅbecReÃÅgie du baÃÇtiment du QueÃÅbecReÃÅgie du logementTribunal administratif des marcheÃÅs financiersTribunal administratif du QueÃÅbecTribunal administratif du travail

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible to serve pleadings on the AGQ by bailiff?
reference.section_content: No, it is not possible to serve pleadings on the AGQ by bailiff since March 23, 2020, since the MontreÃÅal and QueÃÅbec offices of the AGQ are closed in compliance with health authority guidelines. However, service may be made by email, as specifically authorized byMinisterial Order 4251 published March 15, 2020.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How do I serve a pleading on the AGQ?
reference.section_content: Service on the Attorney General of QueÃÅbec in civil matters should be made to: bernardroy@justice.gouv.qc.cafor the districts of Beauharnois, Bedford, Drummond, Gatineau, Iberville, Joliette, Labelle, Laval, Longueuil, MeÃÅgantic, MontreÃÅal, Pontiac, Richelieu, Saint-FrancÃßois, Saint-Hyacinthe and Terrebonne, ortolavoie-rousseau@justice.gouv.qc.cafor other districts.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: COVID-19 legal aid clinic
reference.section_content: A free legal aid hotline now exists for questions about your rights and obligations in the context of the ongoing pandemic. Lawyers across QueÃÅbec can be reached Monday to Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., to answer your legal questions. To reach the COVID-19 legal aid clinic, please dial one of the following numbers: 1 866 699-9729 (toll-free)418 838-6415 (National Capital)514 789-2755 (MontreÃÅal)819 303-4080 (Gatineau)

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is remote swearing in possible?
reference.section_content: Yes. You can read theFrench blog post written on this topic by the spokesperson of the MinisteÃÄre de la Justice du QueÃÅbec. We have also preparedthe following information document.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can family mediation be conducted via teleconference, and if so, are original signatures required on the invoicing form?
reference.section_content: In the current context, remote mediation is possible and even encouraged. Electronic signatures are currently considered sufficient for invoicing purposes. If the electronic signature of one or both parties cannot be obtained, we ask that this be mentioned in a note addressed to the family mediation service so that the invoice can be approved on an exceptional basis during the pandemic. Given the current circumstances, invoices and mediation reports can be sent to the Family Mediation Service via email at:smf@justice.gouv.qc.ca. We ask that mediators using this method keep the originals rather than mailing them to us after the email is sent to avoid duplicating the work of our team.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What measures have been put in place in provincial correctional facilities to protect the health of detainees?
reference.section_content: Since the beginning of the health crisis, the ministeÃÄre de la SeÃÅcuriteÃÅ publique (MSP) has made sure to follow the recommendations of the Institut national de santeÃÅ publique du QueÃÅbec and has implemented numerous measures to protect detainees and MSP correctional services staff. For example, a reminder of the health instructions of the Institut national de santeÃÅ publique du QueÃÅbec;access to water, soap, and cleaning products in the living areas of detainees and to alcohol-based hand sanitizer in areas where they do not have ready access to water and soap;confinement of newly admitted detainees;segregation of prisoners at risk, symptomatic, or affected by COVID-19;mandatory seclusion of staff who have contracted or are likely to have contracted COVID-19;provide protective equipment to staff whose duties require it and make procedural masks available to correctional officers who come into contact with detainees in the course of their duties;restriction of movement in and out of correctional facilities (suspension of programs, no access to gymnasiums, etc.);restriction of entry to and exit from correctional facilities (offenders serving intermittent sentences, visitors, volunteers, appearances, etc.);provide a hotline for all detainees wishing to obtain information on COVID-19.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are all detainees confined to cells in provincial correctional facilities?
reference.section_content: No. Only those individuals with COVID-19 or with symptoms of the disease are secluded and confined to their cells in segregation or quarantine areas, as per the directives of the healthcare department of the correctional facility. A person who is symptomatic is placed in a cell alone and is monitored by the said healthcare department. Since March 26, all inmates admitted to a correctional facility have been quarantined for a period of 14 days before being placed in their respective living areas, as long as they do not show any symptoms.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible to visit detainees in provincial correctional facilities?
reference.section_content: As of March 14, 2020, all visits to detainees, with the exception of lawyers, are suspended until further notice.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: How can a person held in a provincial correctional facility be contacted?
reference.section_content: Since the announcement of the suspension of visits, and for each 15-day period thereafter, all inmates are offered $30 to use the telephone system to contact family and friends. Cell phones are also available for those confined to quarantine areas.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I send clothing and money to a person held in a provincial correctional facility?
reference.section_content: Yes, however, staff at the correctional facility will take several days to process these donations.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it true that meals are being rationed due to the COVID-19 pandemic in provincial correctional facilities?
reference.section_content: No. Meals are being served at the usual frequency and portions have not been reduced in any way. Canteen supplies, subject to availability, remain the same as before the COVID-19 pandemic.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What measures have been put in place to help those held in provincial correctional facilities to better cope with this period?
reference.section_content: Measures have been implemented to help detainees get through this period. For example, telephone call time is offered to each detainee. Movies, books, and board games are available to them. Chaplains are always on site, and a COVID-19 hotline is available to individual detainees.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is there any consideration being given to releasing detainees from provincial correctional facilities?
reference.section_content: In order to protect the health of detainees and correctional facility staff, the execution of intermittent sentences has been suspended since March 20. Individuals under this type of sentence have been granted a medical discharge with the condition that they remain in their homes. The MSP is closely monitoring the situation. For the time being, it is prioritizing, with respect to persons serving a continuous sentence, the terms of release provided for in the Act respecting the QueÃÅbec correctional system, such as temporary absences for medical reasons or for purposes of social reintegration.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are persons held in provincial correctional facilities transported to courthouses for court appearances?
reference.section_content: In order to allow for appearances by detainees that could not be postponed, MSP correctional services worked with the Commission queÃÅbeÃÅcoise des libeÃÅrations conditionnelles du QueÃÅbec to expand the use of videoconferencing for hearings, as well as with the Director of Criminal and Penal Prosecutions, the ministeÃÄre de la Justice, and defence counsel to make use of videoconferencing, video parlours, and telephone appearances whenever possible.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am required to do community service. What happens in the context of COVID-19?
reference.section_content: You must follow the instructions of the Institut national de santeÃÅ publique du QueÃÅbec and stay in your home as much as possible. We suggest that you contact the resource and your correctional services worker to inform them of the situation. If you do not have enough time to complete your work within the prescribed period, your correctional services worker will be approached to collaborate in asking the court to extend the deadline.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers concerning legal and correctional services during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Does the MSP offer support measures for detainees released from provincial correctional facilities during the pandemic?
reference.section_content: There are no pandemic-specific financial measures offered by the MSP. The usual resources are available for assistance in applying to the ministeÃÄre du Travail, de l'Emploi et de la SolidariteÃÅ sociale for benefits or to initiate job search procedures. A correctional services worker can also refer  detainees to the appropriate resources, if need be.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Police are limiting travel in and out of which health regions and territories in QueÃÅbec?
reference.section_content: Essential travel is being allowed. The following regions and territories are currently targeted: CoÃÇte-Nord;Nord-du-QueÃÅbec;Nunavik;Cree Territory of James Bay.  On April 29, 2020, the government announced a plan go gradually reopen the regions spread over several weeks. Starting from May 31, 2020, the following place will be accessible: the CoÃÇte-Nord health regions, except for the Minganie and Golfe-du-Saint-Laurent (Basse CoÃÇte-Nord) RCMs. A reopening plan will be announced later for the following regions and territories: the Minganie and Golfe-du-Saint-Laurent (Basse-CoÃÇte-Nord) RCMs;Nord-du-QueÃÅbec;Nunavik;Cree Territory of James Bay.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Who can access these regions?
reference.section_content: A person whose presence is required under an order issued in a court judgment.A person who is travelling for humanitarian reasons.A person who is travelling to receive health care.A person authorized by a public health director; a  person authorized to act on behalf of a public health director;  physicians.A person who resides in the region.A person transporting goods that are needed for priority services.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: If a person has shared custody of their child, can the person go to one of these regions to get their child?
reference.section_content: Strictly forbidden in all cases if the person has symptoms of COVID-19. Yes, a parent can go to one of these regions to respect the conditions of shared custody, as indicated for example in a judgment rendered by the court or an access agreement. In the case of an out-of-court agreement between the parents, the police at the checkpoint will evaluate the situation and authorize access on a case-by-case basis. In case of doubt, contact the Clinique d‚Äôassistance juridique COVID-19 set up by the QueÃÅbec MinisteÃÄre de la Justice and the Barreau du QueÃÅbec, at1-866-699-9729.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible to go home to one of these regions following a trip abroad?
reference.section_content: Yes, with proof of residence. However, if the person has symptoms of COVID-19, they will have to self-isolate for 14 days in a place indicated by the quarantine officer or another authority.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can a person enter one of these regions to visit a family member in hospital in an end-of-life situation?
reference.section_content: Yes, visiting a family member in hospital at end-of-life is considered a humanitarian situation. However, the trip will not be allowed if the person displays COVID-19 symptoms. Before travelling, make sure the hospital will authorize the visit.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible to deliver parcels to these regions?
reference.section_content: Yes, parcel delivery is considered a priority service. However, delivery persons must not have symptoms of COVID-19.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I have symptoms of COVID-19. Can I use public transit or taxis?
reference.section_content: People who have symptoms of COVID-19 are advised not to use public transit, the subway or taxis to get around, including to or from a medical appointment. They should use a private car. If this is not possible, they may take a taxi to avoid using public transit. The following preventive measures must be rigorously applied: If possible, take taxis with interior surfaces that can be cleaned and disinfected easily (for example, vinyl instead of fabric) and where passengers can sit at least 2 metres away from the driver (for example, a van).Before getting into the taxi, they must wash their hands with an alcohol-based hand rub, such as Purell¬Æor Bacti Control¬Æ.Sit as far as possible from the driver.Wear a mask at all times while in the taxi. If the person does not have a mask, they should cover their mouth and nose with a paper tissue or handkerchief.Open the vehicle‚Äôs windows, weather permitting.Use an alcohol-based hand rub to clean their hands after blowing their nose.Limit contact with the interior surfaces of the taxi.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: I am a taxi driver. What can I do to protect myself and my customers?
reference.section_content: Taxi drivers should wash their hands regularly with soap under warm running water for at least 20 seconds: before eating;before smoking;after going to the toilet;after blowing their nose;wash their hands or use an alcohol-based hand rub, such as Purell¬Æ or Bacti Control¬Æ, after dropping off someone who is sick or hassymptomsof COVID-19. Drivers should also follow these recommendations: Have alcohol-based hand rub or antiseptic wipes on hand at all times.Avoid touching their eyes, nose and mouth.Keep cleaning products in taxis and wash the cleaning product containers every day.Have paper tissues available in the taxi for customers.Clean and disinfect the most frequently used equipment, such as the steering wheel and door handles, several times every day.Disinfect surfaces the person who is sick or who hassymptomsof COVID-19 touched or might have touched.Drivers who havesymptomsof COVID-19 should not work.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can I keep using public transit? How can I protect myself?
reference.section_content: Public transit services continue to operate and are an essential service to enable staff in the health and social services network to travel. QueÃÅbec transit authorities have increased the frequency of maintenance of their vehicles and facilities. Users are still advised to follow the usual health advice and to maintain as far as possible a distance of 2 metres from the other people present. Moreover, they are asked, as far as possible, to modify their usual schedules to limit rush-hour crowds in mass transit systems. It is also important to wash your hands thoroughly for at least 20 seconds before and after using public transit.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is motorcycling allowed?
reference.section_content: Yes, but alone. However, the same instructions pertaining to travel apply, that is, such travel must be confined to medical reasons and to go to work when teleworking is impossible.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Leases will be up soon and, despite the situation, owners still want to show apartments. Do we have to limit viewings?
reference.section_content: Given the current situation, public health authorities recommend suspending apartment viewings for now. If, despite this, you want to show an apartment, you must take precautions. First, it is important to postpone all viewings of apartments where the tenants have COVID-19 or are self-isolating because they have flu-like symptoms or have returned from travelling. You must take the following measures before the viewing: provide any relevant information about the apartments to the viewers to make sure of their interest;make sure that viewers have not been travelling in the last 14 days and do not have any flu-like symptoms;ask viewers to wash their hands before they enter apartments; You must take the following measures during the viewing: limit the number of people, preferably to one viewer at a time;keep the viewing as short as possible;ask everyone who is there to keep at least one to two metres apart;ask viewers not to touch anything in the apartments; After each viewing, it is important to disinfect all the doorknobs in the apartments.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can loved ones be asked to help with moving?
reference.section_content: Moving companies are included on the list of priority services and activities. Moreover, the Institut national de santeÃÅ publique du QueÃÅbec has issuedtemporary recommendations for moversto prevent the risk of spreading COVID-19. If you cannot rely on movers and must obtain help for your move, it is possible to call on your loved ones while abiding by certain criteria. First, make sure that no one displays COVID-19 symptoms, has returned from a trip within the past 14 days or has been in contact with infected individuals. You must also limit as much as possible the number of people present and the duration of their presence. As far as possible, always remain 2 metres from each other. Frequently wash your hands for at least 20 seconds with warm water and soap. Abide by the other basic health recommendations: avoid direct contact when greeting other people, such as shaking hands; cough into the crook of your elbow; avoid touching your face; and so on.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it possible for a person who is moving to one of these regions to do so?
reference.section_content: Yes, if the person who is moving is settling in his principal residence and does not display any COVID-19 symptoms. Moving companies are considered priority services. However, moving employees cannot carry out their work if they have symptoms of COVID-19.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: What good health practices should be adopted when moving?
reference.section_content: TheSocieÃÅteÃÅ d‚Äôhabitation du QueÃÅbec(SHQ) has put online a guide to good health practices to be adopted by tenants who must move soon. The document emphasizes the precautionary measures to be taken to avoid the risk of spreading the COVID-19 virus. Moreover, it offers tips to be followed before, during and after a move and indicates other sources of government information related to moving. The guide is available free of charge on theSHQ website.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can you define what a gathering is?
reference.section_content: A gathering is when 2 or more people who do not live at the same address get together.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is it a good idea to have a ‚ÄúCOVID party‚Äù so that my child will develop immunity?
reference.section_content: No. Voluntarily exposing your child to someone who has COVID‚Äê19 is not recommended. While it is true that many children only develop mild symptoms, we know very little about the virus. It is impossible to guarantee that your child will be protected against COVID‚Äê19 after having the disease or to predict how long they would be protected for.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Is hosting in one‚Äôs home loved ones or family members who reside in another dwelling or going for a walk with them allowed?
reference.section_content: All indoor and outdoor gatherings are prohibited with individuals who do not live in the same dwelling, including members of the immediate family living in another dwelling. As for walks, everyone must maintain a minimum distance of 2 metres except in the case of individuals who live in the same private residence. Beginning May22, outdoor gatherings will be permitted provided that specific measures are respected. First, not more than 10people must be present at a gathering. Also, they should include people from a maximum of three households. As a reminder, those people living at the same address form a household. Obviously, a distance of at least 2metres must be kept between those people who are not from the same household. The use of a face covering is strongly recommended.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can two partners who do not live together see each other if they do not have any symptoms and have not been travelling?
reference.section_content: We are asking people in this situation to cooperate and use their judgement. The answer to this question depends on a number of factors: do the people live alone, are they still working, etc. If they decide to see each other, they must make sure: they have both followed and are following thehealth recommendations for everyoneissued by the public health authorities;they are both healthy or are notvulnerable(e.g., chronically ill or 70 years of age or older);neither of them has symptoms of fever, new or worse cough, difficulty breathing or sudden loss of smell without a stuffy nose, with or without loss of taste;neither of them have been told toself-isolate;neither of them live with a vulnerable person (e.g., chronically ill or 70 years of age or older). If partners cannot see each other, they are advised to stay in touch by using other ways of communicating (telephone calls, text messages, social media, digital photos, arranging a time to say hello from their balcony, dinner for two by Skype or another platform, etc.).

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Are group bike rides allowed if cyclists stay 2 metres apart?
reference.section_content: All gatherings are prohibited at the moment, including group bike rides. Even if cyclists want to follow the 2-metre physical distancing rule, it might be difficult to do so all the time, since the distance between cyclists changes constantly depending on their speed and road conditions. In addition, at this time, there are few studies to support or refute the safety of riding 2 metres apart. Therefore, it is preferable not to go on group rides.

reference.page_title: Questions and answers on transportation, travel and gatherings during the COVID-19 pandemic
section_headers: Can meetings of co-owners and meetings of the board of directors of a divided co-ownership be held at a distance? If so, how do they work?
reference.section_content: Under order 2020-029 of April26, 2020, it is possible to hold any meeting, session, or assembly that must be held in person, including meetings of co-owners and meetings of the board of directors of a co-ownership, using technological means that allow all participants to communicate immediately with each other.
